Details: Both outputs provide comprehensive Hive to BigQuery conversion analyses with similar structural approaches but notable differences in depth and implementation details. Agent_1 offers a more concise overview focusing on high-level metrics and conversion strategies, while Agent_2 provides detailed SQL code analysis with specific line-by-line complexity assessment. Both achieve the core objective of analyzing conversion complexity and providing actionable migration guidance.

Both outputs address the same core objective of Hive to BigQuery conversion analysis. They share similar analytical frameworks covering complexity metrics, syntax differences, manual adjustments, and optimization techniques. However, Agent_2 provides more granular detail with actual SQL code analysis (lines 45-84) while Agent_1 focuses on higher-level strategic guidance. The semantic intent aligns well but with different levels of technical depth.

Both outputs follow nearly identical 7-section structures: Script Overview, Complexity Metrics, Syntax Differences, Manual Adjustments, Conversion Complexity, Optimization Techniques, and API Cost Estimation. Agent_2 includes additional SQL code content (lines 45-84) that Agent_1 lacks. The logical flow and decomposition approach are highly similar, but Agent_2 provides more detailed subsection breakdowns within each major section.

Minor issues include: inconsistent complexity scoring methodology (line 45: '70/100' without clear criteria), and some generalized statements about function mappings that could be more specific. Improve consistency in complexity scoring methodology and reduce redundancy in technical descriptions. The included SQL code is valuable but could benefit from inline comments explaining BigQuery-specific optimizations.

Both outputs would benefit from standardized complexity scoring criteria and more detailed cost-benefit analysis for different migration approaches. Consider adding timeline estimates for conversion activities.
